sentenceInfoList.sentence: LA NIÑA DEL VIGÍA
UN faro es un edificio muy elevado, que generalmente tiene la forma de una torre, con un gran fanal en la parte superior.

Este fanal se enciende todas las noches, y como su luz recibe considerable aumento con la ayuda de lentes y de grandes reflectores, puede ser vista á una distancia considerable, y guiar de esta manera á los navegantes durante la noche.
Los faros se colocan generalmente en las rocas más elevadas, cerca de la orilla del mar, ó en los puntos en que hay peligro para los buques....
Hay hombres encargados de cuidar los faros; que viven en ellos y encienden todas las noches aquella luz....
Estos hombres se llaman vigías, y tienen que ser empleados sumamente fieles....
En uno de los faros de la costa de Valencia vivían un vigía y su hija única, niña de unos ocho años, que se llamaba Mariquita.
El faro estaba situado en un peñasco que sólo se unía á la tierra firme por medio de una calzada estrecha, construida sobre una lengua baja de arena y rocas.
No se podía atravesar esta calzada sino durante un espacio de tres horas, dos veces al día, pues durante todo el tiempo restante estaba cubierta por las aguas que crecían con la marea.
Una tarde el vigía....
cruzó la calzada para comprar algunas provisiones, dejando sola á su hijita en la torre del faro.
Mientras el padre apresuraba el paso hacia el pueblo vecino..., tres hombres de mala traza, ocultos detrás de unas rocas, espiaban sus movimientos.
Eran raqueros, gente que vive del saqueo de los buques que naufragan en las costas.

Sabiendo ellos que los buques que habían de pasar aquella noche, se estrellarían contra los arrecifes si el fanal no les advertía el riesgo, y que entonces tendrían ellos una buena presa, se propusieron apoderarse del vigía.

Llegado que hubo éste á la costa, salieron los raqueros de su escondrijo y le derribaron al suelo; le ataron de pies y manos, y le dejaron bajo la custodia de uno de ellos mientras los demás se dirigían á la playa.
Mariquita entretanto esperaba impaciente la vuelta de su padre.
La noche se acercaba, y había barruntos de tempestad, pues ya se veían las olas estrellarse contra las rocas y se oía el viento bramar alrededor de la torre.
Dieron las seis; y la niña no ignoraba que pronto la marea subiría.
Dieron las siete; miró á la costa, pero no vió á su padre.

Á las siete y media ya la marea llegaba al borde de la calzada; sólo las cimas de las más altas rocas se descubrían sobre el nivel del mar, y muy pronto todo desapareció debajo de las turbulentas aguas.
—¡Papá!
¡Papá mío!
—exclamó la acongojada niña—¿dónde estás?
¿me has olvidado?
En este momento se acordó de que era hora de encender las lámparas; pero ¿qué podía hacer la pobre niña estando las mechas demasiado altas para su estatura?
Cogió unos cuantos fósforos é hizo luz; probó si con una escalera podía alcanzar al lugar apetecido, pero aunque la puso sobre una mesa, vió que todavía le faltaba un poco para llegar á las mechas.

Ya iba á sentarse descorazonada y afligida cuando se acordó de un gran libro en que su padre acostumbraba leer; lo trajo, y colocándolo debajo de la escalera, la elevó lo suficiente para poder encender las mechas.
Los rayos de luz del fanal se derramaron sobre la expansión de las aguas, ya embravecidas por la tempestad, y los buques pudieron evitar aquella noche el peligro que los amenazaba.
En cuanto vieron los raqueros que el fanal estaba encendido, pusieron en libertad al vigía y huyeron de aquel sitio.

La mañana siguiente, como ya había bajado la marea, el vigía pudo llegar al faro, donde su hijita se arrojó á sus brazos y le contó los trabajos que había pasado aquella horrenda noche en la torre del fanal.

longDef: accusative of ella, ello (when the antecedent's implied gender is feminine), and usted (when referring to a woman); her, it, you (formal)
impersonal neuter pronoun (accusative) in certain colloquial phrases: it, this
La sabe toda.  ― He/she knows everything (it all)
¡Dónde la viste!  ― Where have you seen this!
No te la creo.  ― I don't believe you.
(Contraction) of the, from the (+ a masculine noun in singular).

vigía.shortDef: lookout, watchtower (vantage point with a view of the surrounding area)
longDef: (Noun) lookout, watchtower (vantage point with a view of the surrounding area)
(Noun) (nautical) reef (chain or range of rocks, sand, or coral protruding from the surface of the water)
¡Mira al cielo, hay un águila! - Look at the sky, there's an eagle!
¡Manos arriba, tengo un arma! - Hands up, I have a gun!
Yo soy de los Estados Unidos. ― I am from the United States.

Errar es humano. ― To err is human.
2007, El Sueño de Morfeo, Nada es Suficiente:

¿Qué voy a ser si te he dado lo que soy? ― What am I going to be if I've given you what I am?
2007, El Sueño de Morfeo, Para Toda la Vida:
Si fueras una gota de agua, nadie volvería a tener sed ― If you were a drop of water, no one would thirst again
(Verb) to be (in the passive voice sense)
La guitarra fue tocada. ― The guitar was played.
Tengo un coche muy caro. ― I have a very expensive car.

Rafael Nadal eleva, con mascarilla, su 13ª Copa de los Mosqueteros en un ambiente que nada tiene que ver con el de otras ocasiones. ― Rafael Nadal, wearing a mask, lifts up his 13th Musketeers' Trophy in at atmosphere nothing like any other times.
Él dice que está triste. ― He says that he is sad.
Llego más tarde que tú. ― I am arriving later than you.
la estrella que está en la película ― the star who is in the movie
la mujer con la que yo hablé ― the woman with whom I spoke
Synonyms: en general, por lo general, en líneas generales
Ella tiene seis hermanos. ― She has six brothers.
Tengo una pluma. ― I have a pen.
(Verb) (transitive) to have, possess, to be (a condition or quality)
Usted tiene suerte. ― You are lucky. (literally, "You have luck.")
¿Quién tiene razón? ― Who is right? (literally, "Who has reason?")
¡Tiene que haber otra forma! ― There has to be another way!

inflection of formar:
third-person singular present indicative
second-person singular imperative
(Preposition) of; 's; used after the thing owned and before the owner
Constitución española de 1812 ― Spanish constitution of 1812
la cola del perro ― the dog’s tail
(Preposition) from (with the source or provenance of or at)
Soy de España. ― I’m from Spain.
The name of the Latin-script letter D.
Una manzana al día mantiene al médico en lejanía. - An apple a day keeps the doctor away.
Sólo hay una ruta - There is only one route.

inflection of torrar:
first/third-person singular present subjunctive
third-person singular imperative
Yo cuento con ustedes. ― I count on you.
Estoy en casa. ― I'm at home.
Estoy sentado en la computadora. ― I'm sitting at the computer.
en esta página ― on this page
en la caja en la mesa ― in the box on the table

parte.shortDef: part, section, portion, share, piece, bit, cut, proportion
longDef: (Noun) part, section, portion, share, piece, bit, cut, proportion
Quiero una parte de la acción. Me la merezco. ― I want a piece of the action. I deserve it.

El jefe del recién formado cartel también quería una parte del trato, así como su parte justa del producto y su benificio. ― The leader of the newly formed cartel also wanted a cut of the deal, as well as his fair share of the product and its profit.
Ve con tu ruido a otra parte. ― Take your noise somewhere else.

inflection of partir:
third-person singular present indicative
second-person singular imperative
uh, well (space filler in a conversation)

se.shortDef: third person (also used for usted and ustedes) reflexive direct or indirect object oneself, himself, herself, itself, yourself; each other; one another
longDef: (Pronoun) third person (also used for usted and ustedes) reflexive direct or indirect object oneself, himself, herself, itself, yourself; each other; one another
Juan se lava. ― Juan washes himself.
Juan se lava la cara. ― Juan washes his own face. (literally, "Juan to himself washes the face.")
Juan y María se aman. ― Juan and María love each other.
(Pronoun) used to convey the meaning of the English passive voice in the third person and with usted and ustedes
¿Cómo se llama? ― What is your name? (literally, "How do you call yourself?")
Se dice que... ― It is said that... (literally, "It says itself that...")
Aquí se habla español ― Spanish is spoken here / They speak Spanish here. (literally, "One speaks Spanish here, Spanish speaks itself here.")

encender.shortDef: to incite, to inflame, tokindle, tolight
longDef: Julio encendió la fogata. ― Julio ignited the campfire.
(Verb) to turn on, switch on, power up
María encendió la máquina. ― María turned on the machine.

todas.shortDef: plural of toda; all, all of
longDef: plural of toda; all, all of

noche.shortDef: night (the period between sunset and sunrise)
longDef: (Noun) night (the period between sunset and sunrise)
durante la noche ― at night / overnight / at night time

y.shortDef:
and
1605, Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra, Don Quijote de la Mancha1, Chapter I:
longDef: Es, pues, de saber que este sobredicho hidalgo, los ratos que estaba ocioso —que eran los más del año—, se daba a leer libros de caballerías, con tanta afición y gusto, que olvidó casi de todo punto el ejercicio de la caza y aun la administración de su hacienda; y llegó a tanto su curiosidad y desatino en esto, que vendió muchas hanegas de tierra de sembradura para comprar libros de caballerías en que leer, y, así, llevó a su casa todos cuantos pudo haber dellos. ― You must know, then, that the above-named gentleman whenever he was at leisure (which was mostly all the year round) gave himself up to reading books of chivalry with such ardour and avidity that he almost entirely neglected the pursuit of his field-sports, and even the management of his property; and to such a pitch did his eagerness and infatuation go that he sold many an acre of tillageland to buy books of chivalry to read, and brought home as many of them as he could get.

como.shortDef: as (introducing a basis of comparison or equality)
longDef: (Conjunction) as (introducing a basis of comparison or equality)
¿Tienes tanta hambre como yo? ― Are you as hungry as I am?
Como nunca vio mi mensaje, vamos sin ella. ― Since she never saw my message, we're going without her.
as (to such an extent or degree)
No es tan alta como nosotras. ― She's not as tall as us.
Hemos esperado como media hora. ― We've waited like half an hour.
as (in the manner or role specified)
Mis ahijados me ven como un tío. ― My godchildren see me as an uncle.
Synonyms: por ejemplo, como por ejemplo
Algunos países de Asia, como Laos y Vietnam... ― Some countries in Asia, such as Laos and Vietnam...
first-person singular present indicative of comer
Su casa es grande. - His house is big.
Su madre es muy simpática. - Her mother is very nice.
¿Cómo está su familia? - How is your family?
¿Dónde está su coche? - Where is your car?
la luz extinguida ― the extinguished light
first-person singular present indicative of aumentar
Muchas gracias por su ayuda. ― Many thanks for your help.

inflection of ayudar:
third-person singular present indicative
second-person singular imperative
¿Puedo ayudarle en algo? ― Can I help you in any way?

Su preocupación no me ayuda nada. ― His concern does not help me at all.
2001, John MacArthur, Cómo Ser Padres Cristianos Exitosos [How to Be Succesful Christian Parents], Editorial Portavoz, →ISBN:

Si no ayudas a tus hijos a escoger y no les ayudas a aprender a seleccionar por sí mismos las compañías adecuadas, será inevitable que las malas compañías los seleccionen a ellos. ― If you don't help your children to choose and you don't help them to learn to choose suitable company for themselves, bad company will inevitably choose them.

grande.shortDef: (after the noun or predicatively) big, large
longDef: (Adjective) (after the noun or predicatively) big, large
Synonyms: (for cloth, shoe, place) amplio, voluminoso
Hace cinco años los reflectores de la violencia contra periodistas estaban en otro lado, en los estados del norte. ― (please add an English translation of this quotation)
¿Puedes acompañarme mañana? ― Could you come with me tomorrow?
No puedes salir ya que no tienes permiso. ― You can't go out since you're not allowed.
No puedo hablar francés. ― I can't speak French.
Podría ayudar si me dejaran. ― I could help you if you would let me.
(Verb) (El Salvador, colloquial, reflexive) to be familiar with something, or with somebody's personality
¿Te podés el número de tu prima? ― Do you know your cousin's phone number?
Como entrenador, tengo que poderme bien a todos mis jugadores. ― As a coach, I must know my players really well.

vista.shortDef: sight, vision, eyesight (the ability to see)
longDef: (Noun) sight, vision, eyesight (the ability to see)
(Noun) sight (the act of seeing or witnessing)

inflection of vestir:
first/third-person singular present subjunctive
third-person singular imperative
(Verb) to dress, to clothe, to attire
No podrían acertar a un elefante a esta distancia. ― They couldn’t hit an elephant at this distance.

inflection of distanciar:
third-person singular present indicative
second-person singular imperative

esta.shortDef: alternative spelling of ésta This one
longDef: alternative spelling of ésta This one
Accusative form of ellos or ustedes
Plural masculine or neuter pronoun, e.g. los que no hablan, "those who do not speak"
Durante el verano nos gusta ir al parque acuático. ― In the summer we like to go to the water park.
Acabo de enterarme de que me ha estado mintiendo durante años. ― I just found out that he's been lying to me for years.
Teresa es más lista que su hermano. ― Teresa is more clever than her brother.

Hay más de cien personas aquí. ― There are more than a hundred people here.
1605, Miguel de Cervantes, "Capítulo I", in El ingenioso hidalgo Don Quijote de la Mancha, Primera parte:

Una olla de algo más vaca que carnero, salpicón las más noches, duelos y quebrantos los sábados, lantejas los viernes, algún palomino de añadidura los domingos, consumían las tres partes de su hacienda ― A pot of stew of rather more beef than mutton, a salad on most nights, scraps on Saturdays, lentils on Fridays, and a pigeon or so extra on Sundays, made away with three-quarters of his income.
(Adverb) (with definite article) most; -est (used to make superlatives)
Teresa es la más inteligente de la clase. ― Teresa is the most intelligent in her class.
la cosa más grande ― the biggest thing
uno más uno es igual a dos ― one plus one is equal to two

cerca.shortDef: close, near, around, about, nearly, nigh (referring to quantity or time-related)
longDef: (Adverb) close, near, around, about, nearly, nigh (referring to quantity or time-related)
(Adverb) close, near, around, nigh, at hand, close at hand, in sight (spatially)
fence (a thin artificial barrier that separates two pieces of land or a house perimeter)

inflection of cercar:
third-person singular present indicative
second-person singular imperative

inflection of orillar:
third-person singular present indicative
second-person singular imperative

mar.shortDef:
sea
2008, Cécile Corbel (lyrics and music), "En la mar [In the Middle of the Sea]", in Songbook vol. 2‎[4] (CD), performed by Cécile Corbel, Brittany: Keltia Musique:
longDef: En la mar hay una torreEn la torre una ventanaEn la ventana hay una hijaQue a los marineros ama. ― In the middle of the sea there's a towerIn the tower there's a windowAt the window there's a maidenWho loves the sailors.

ó.shortDef: or (once used instead of o near numerals to avoid confusion with a zero: 2 ó 3)
longDef: or (once used instead of o near numerals to avoid confusion with a zero: 2 ó 3)

punto.shortDef: point (a specific spot, location, or place)
longDef: (Noun) point (a specific spot, location, or place)
Tienes cinco puntos. ― You have five points.
Ese artículo cuesta tres puntos. ― That item costs three points.
first-person singular present indicative of puntar

haber.shortDef: to have (to do something, auxiliary verb)
longDef: (Verb) (auxiliary verb taking past participle to build various perfect tenses) to have
He trabajado muy duro durante este mes. ― I have worked very hard during this month.
Mi hermanito me pidió más chocolate, pero ya le había dado demasiado. ― My little brother asked me for more chocolate, but I had already given him too much.
first-person singular present indicative of peligrar
La niña compró un regalo de navidad para su abuela.  ― The girl bought a Christmas gift for her grandmother.
Ahora me gustaría hacer un truco de magia para ustedes.  ― I'd now like to perform a magic trick for you all.
(Preposition) to, in order to, so, for (expressing the intended purpose of an action)
Estudio cada noche sin descanso para conseguir un trabajo decente al fin de todo esto.  ― I study every night tirelessly so that I get a decent job at the end of all this.
Voy a salir temprano para evitar el tráfico.  ― I am going to leave early to avoid traffic.

inflection of parar:
third-person singular present indicative
second-person singular imperative

inflection of parir:
first/third-person singular present subjunctive
third-person singular imperative

buque.shortDef:
ship, vessel
1981, Gabriel García Márquez, Crónica de una muerte anunciada:
longDef: El día en que lo iban a matar, Santiago Nasar se levantó as las 5.30 de la mañana para esperar el buque en que llegaba el obispo. ― (please add an English translation of this quotation)
(Verb) (transitive, intransitive) to take care of, to care for
A usted le sugiero que cuide a sus propios niños, y yo voy a preocuparme de los míos. ― I suggest that you care for your own children and I'll worry about mine.
(Verb) (transitive) to look after, to look out for, to keep an eye on, to guard, to protect, to watch over, to watch out for (implies doing so with care)
Por favor, cuida de mi hija después de que muera. ― Please, look out for my daughter after I'm gone.
El perro leal siempre cuida la casa. ― The loyal dog always guards the house.
(Verb) (intransitive) to make a living, to live on
Vive de migas, nada más. ― He lives on crumbs, nothing more.

aquella.shortDef: alternative spelling of aquélla That one
longDef: alternative spelling of aquélla That one

estos.shortDef: alternative spelling of éstos These ones.
longDef: alternative spelling of éstos These ones.
Te estuve llamando a voces. ― I was summoning you by voice.

Me llamó con la mano para que me acercase. ― [He] summoned me with [his] hand in order to bring me near.
to call (on the telephone)
Te llaman desde París. ― They are calling you from Paris.
Que me llamen a las siete. ― May they call me at seven o'clock.

Ha llamado a Maribel. ― [He] has called Maribel.
to knock (on a door)

Entren sin llamar. ― Enter without knocking.
to ring (a doorbell)
¿Cómo van a llamar al niño? ― How are they going to refer to the child?
Eso yo lo llamo un auténtico robo. ― I refer to that as an authentic robbery.
La llamó de todo. ― [He] referred to her about everything.
Irene siempre ha sido fiel a su marido. ― Irene has always been faithful to her husband.
Sé fiel a quien eres. ― Be true to who you are.
Los perros son fieles. ― Dogs are loyal.
Uno más uno es igual a dos. - One plus one equals two.
Uno de los dos tiene que ceder. - One of the two has to give in.
vivir a costa de ― to live on the expense of
a toda costa ― at all costs
el único sobreviviente ― the sole survivor
único en su clase/especie/género ― one of a kind
el año que viene ― next year
el año vigente ― the current year
va para un año que no te veo ― it's been a year since I saw you
con los años me cuesta cada vez más estar feliz ― over the years I find it harder and harder to be happy
dentro de un par de años ― in a couple of years' time
el mejor año de mi vida ― the best year of my life
todos los años es igual ― it's the same thing year on year
en sus años mozo ― in her childhood years
Tengo veinte años. ― I'm twenty [years old].
Depende de los años que tenga. ― It depends how old it is.
(Article) feminine singular definite article used before nouns which start with a stressed /a/:
el alma, las almas ― the soul, the souls
el hacha, las hachas ― the axe, the axes
(Verb) (intransitive) to be (have a temporary or permanent location in space)
Estoy en casa. ― I am at home.
(Verb) (intransitive) to be (denotes a copula, in a transient fashion)
El tiempo estaba frío/caliente. ― The weather was cold/hot [back then].
(Verb) to situate, to place, to put, to position

unir.shortDef: to connect, to unite, to join, to bind, to attach
longDef: ¡Únete al sindicato! ― Join up with the union!

tierra.shortDef: (geography) land, ground (the part of Earth which is not covered by oceans or other bodies of water)
longDef: (Noun) (geography) land, ground (the part of Earth which is not covered by oceans or other bodies of water)
(Noun) (geology) earth, soil (the unconsolidated mineral or organic material on the immediate surface of the earth)
Alternative letter-case form of Tierra ("Earth") (our planet, third from the Sun)

inflection of firmar:
first/third-person singular present subjunctive
third-person singular imperative
Él no quiso firmar el papel y por ende, no se pudo hacer nada. ― He didn't want to sign the paper and as a result, nothing could be done.
Lo hice por ti. - I did it for you.
Escrito por Juan. - Written by Juan.
Entra por la puerta principal. - Enter through the main door.

medio.shortDef: half (one of two equal parts of any whole)
longDef: (Noun) half (one of two equal parts of any whole)

Synonym: mitad
(mathematics) half (any fraction with a denominator of 2)
(historical) medio, half-celemin (a traditional unit of dry measure equivalent to about 2.3 L)

Synonyms: maquila (Spain); copín (Asturias); copino
(historical) medio (the usual container used to measure medios)
(historical, Guatemala, Colombia, Ecuador, Venezuela) medio, half-real (a former coin)
(historical, Dominican Republic) medio, half-peso (a former coin)
(historical, Ecuador) medio, half-sucre (a former coin)
(historical, Panama) medio, half-balboa (a former coin)
(historical, Bolivia) medio, half-boliviano (a former coin)
(historical, Mexico) medio, half-octavo (a former coin equal to 1⁄16 real)
(slang, Mexico, Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Costa Rica, Peru) medio (following decimalization, the notional amount of 6+1⁄4 centavos as half of the notional amount of a 1⁄8-peseta real and later by extension any 5 centavo coin)
(Noun) middle (the part of anything located halfway between its ends or extremes in time or along one dimension in space)

Se despertó en medio de la noche. ― She awoke in the middle of the night.
(sports) midfielder, halfback (a person forming part of the middle or central defensive or offensive line, especially in soccer)
(spiritualism) Synonym of médium ("medium") (a person claiming to the ability to communicate with the dead)
(politics, business) cut (the payment demanded to permit or facilitate some action, especially as a bribe)
(philosophy) middle term (the general category that appears in both premises and disappears in the conclusion)
(mathematics, usually in the plural) mean (the second and third terms of a proportion)
half (of or related to one of two equal divisions of a whole)
(inexact) half (of or related to any large proportion of a whole)
Medio Nueva York fue a los toros. ― Half of New York went to the bullfight.
half, incompletely (indicating an action interrupted or only partially done)
half, kind of (particularly used to partially soften negative descriptions)
Es medio idiota. ― He’s a bit of an idiot... He’s kind of an idiot...
first-person singular present indicative of mediar
(Verb) to center, to give a central, medium or average value

Synonym: apretado
2023 July 24, Carlos E. Cué, "La resistencia del PSOE y Sumar frustra la mayoría del PP y Vox y deja abiertas todas las posibilidades", in El País‎[1]:

Los números son tan estrechos que dejan la gobernabilidad en el aire: el bloque actual tendría 172 escaños, y necesitaría al menos la abstención de Junts para hacer presidente a Pedro Sánchez, y el bloque de la derecha solo tiene 171 siempre que el PNV se mantenga con el PSOE. ― The numbers are so tight that they leave governance up in the air: the current bloc would have 172 seats, and would need at least the abstention of Junts to make Pedro Sánchez prime minister, and the right-wing bloc only has 171 as long as the EAJ-PNV remains with the PSOE.
first-person singular present indicative of estrechar
La pluma de mi tía está sobre la mesa. ― My aunt's pen is on the table.
Dime algo sobre ti. ― Tell me something about yourself.

inflection of sobrar:
first/third-person singular present subjunctive
third-person singular imperative
(Verb) to get off, to get down, to climb down, to step down, to get out (e.g., of/from a platform or vehicle)
Bajé del taxi. ― I got out of the taxi.
Bajaron del árbol. ― They climbed down the tree.
arena muerta ― pure sand (useless for cultivation)

inflection of arenar:
third-person singular present indicative
second-person singular imperative

sino.shortDef: but (after a negative clause) (i.e., "but rather", "but only", or "but rather only")
longDef: (Conjunction) but (after a negative clause) (i.e., "but rather", "but only", or "but rather only")
No es cantante, sino actor. ― He is not a singer, but an actor.
(Noun) space (physical extent across two or three dimensions)
first-person singular present indicative of espaciar

hora.shortDef: hour (a time period of sixty minutes)
longDef: (Noun) hour (a time period of sixty minutes)
Hay veinticuatro horas por el día. ― There are twenty-four hours in a day.
(Noun) time (the moment, as indicated by a clock or similar device)
¿Qué hora es? ― What time is it?
Ya es hora de ir. ― It's time to go.
Lo hizo dos veces. ― He did it twice.
cada vez que te veo ― every time that I see you
(Contraction) Contraction of a el ("at the, to the").
(Noun) day (a period from midnight to the following midnight)

El resto della concluían sayo de velarte, calzas de velludo para las fiestas, con sus pantuflos de lo mesmo, y los días de entresemana se honraba con su vellorí de lo más fino. ― The rest of it went in a doublet of fine cloth and velvet breeches and shoes to match for holidays, while on week-days he made a brave figure in his best homespun.
Pues me voy. ― I'll go, then.
Es el mismo gato, pues tiene la misma apariencia. ― It is the same cat, since it has the same appearance.
Todos somos jóvenes. ― We are all young.
todo tipo de ― every type/kind/sort of; all kinds/sorts of
Toda persona es un individuo. ― Every person is an individual.
todo lo que dijiste ― everything that you said

No tengo tiempo. ― I don't have time. / I haven't got time.
1909, Casiodoro de Reina, Biblia Reina-Valera, Juan 7:6:
Díceles entonces Jesús: Mi tiempo aun no ha venido; mas vuestro tiempo siempre está presto. ― Then Jesus says to them: My time has not yet come; but your time is always ready.
(Noun) a while, period of time, long time, length of time, indeterminate amount of time
¿Cuánto tiempo hace que vives aquí? ― How long have you been living here?
Amiga, ha pasado demasiado tiempo. ― Friend, it's been too long.
Hace tiempo que yo no tomaba un buen trago. ― It's been a while since I've had a good drink.
remnant (small portion remaining of a larger thing or group)

inflection of marear:
third-person singular present indicative
second-person singular imperative
Siempre llega tarde. ― He/she always arrives late.
por la tarde ― in the afternoon
demasiado poco, demasiado tarde ― too little, too late

inflection of tardar:
first/third-person singular present subjunctive
third-person singular imperative
(Verb) to buy (to obtain in exchange of money or goods)

Antonym: vender
2015 October 22, "¿Lavadora? Nunca. Cómo conseguir que mis zapatillas blancas sigan blancas", in El País‎[1]:
Si están demasiado sucios, pase por una mercería y cómprese unos nuevos cada cierto tiempo. ― (please add an English translation of this quotation)

algunas.shortDef: Feminine plural of alguno; some (some people)
longDef: Feminine plural of alguno; some (some people)

dejar.shortDef: to leave, abandon, to let, allow
longDef: Dejé la cerveza arriba. ― I left the beer upstairs.
(Verb) (transitive) to leave, to keep (to allow to continue)
Me gusta dejar la luz encendida. ― I like to keep/leave the light on.
Supongo que podríamos dejar el restaurante abierto un poco más. ― I suppose we could keep the restaurant open a little bit longer.
Solo quiero salir. ― I just want to leave.
No solo... sino también... ― Not only... but also...

mientras.shortDef: (with the indicative) while, whilst, as (at the same time as)
longDef: (Conjunction) (with the indicative) while, whilst, as (at the same time as)
Quédate aquí con los chicos mientras hablo con la gerente. ― Stay here with the kids while I talk with the manager.
(Conjunction) (with the subjunctive) as long as, so long as (expressing a condition)
Mientras llueva, me quedaré en casa. ― As long as it rains, I'll stay at home.
(Verb) (reflexive) to rush, to hasten [+ a (infinitive) = to do something]

paso.shortDef: pace (rough distance of a brisk stride)
longDef: (Noun) pace (rough distance of a brisk stride)
(Noun) (historical, measure) paso, Spanish pace (a traditional unit of length equivalent to about 1.4 m)
first-person singular present indicative of pasar

pasar.shortDef: to pass, to spend (time), to happen
longDef: (Verb) (transitive) to pass, to hand, to slip
estas cosas pasan ― these things happen
Ya me ha pasado. ― It has already happened to me.
Сaminaremos hacia el centro de la ciudad. ― We'll walk towards the center of the city.
El cohete se dirige hacia la luna. ― The rocket is heading towards the Moon.
(Noun) the common people, the working classes
first-person singular present indicative of poblar

vecino.shortDef: neighbour (a person living on adjacent or nearby land)
longDef: (Noun) neighbour (a person living on adjacent or nearby land)
(Noun) (especially in the plural) a resident or inhabitant of an area, especially of a neighborhood or a village

inflection of trazar:
third-person singular present indicative
second-person singular imperative
(Verb) (transitive) to draw, to plot, to chart
Debemos trazar un rumbo hacia la nave comandante. ― We should plot a course for the command ship.
first-person singular present indicative of ocultar
(Verb) to spy, to spy on (act as a spy)

movimiento.shortDef: movement (physical motion between points in space)
longDef: (Noun) movement (physical motion between points in space)
(Noun) movement (a trend in various fields or social categories)
el Saqueo de Roma ― the Sack of Rome
first-person singular present indicative of saquear
Sé que volverá. ― I know that it'll come back.
Lo siguiente que sé... ― Next thing I know...
que yo sepa ― as far as I know
Si tu supieras... ― If you knew...
(Verb) to know how to do something
Sabe hablar español. ― He knows how to speak Spanish.
(Verb) (also takes a reflexive pronoun) to crash

El coche se estrelló contra la pared. ― The car crashed into the wall.
2017, Tyto Alba, Fellini en Roma, Astiberri, →ISBN, page 9:

¡Dios mío! ¡Nos vamos a estrellar! ¡Vamos a morir todos! ― (please add an English translation of this quotation)
2022 September 4, Jesús A. Cañas, Reuters, "Un avión privado que había despegado de Jerez de la Frontera se estrella en Letonia", in El País‎[1]:

Un avión privado se ha estrellado la noche de este domingo frente a las costas de Letonia, según ha anunciado el servicio de rescate de Suecia, y después de que dos aviones militares lo siguieran durante parte de su trayectoria. ― (please add an English translation of this quotation)
la lucha contra el prejuicio ― the fight against prejudice

le.shortDef: To her, for her (dative form of ella)
longDef: To her, for her (dative form of ella)
To him, for him (dative form of él)
To you, for you (dative form of usted, ello, lo)

l.shortDef: The 12th letter of the Spanish alphabet
longDef: The 12th letter of the Spanish alphabet

advertir.shortDef: to advise, to givenotice, togivewarning, totakenoticeof, towarn
longDef: (Verb) (transitive with de or with no preposition) to warn
Te advierto que no lo hagas otra vez. ― I'm warning you not to do it again.
Le advertí del peligro. ― I warned him of the danger.
Advertí algunos errores en su informe. ― I noticed some mistakes in his report.

riesgo.shortDef: chance; risk; the possibility of harm or an unfavorable outcome from random chance
longDef: (Noun) chance; risk; the possibility of harm or an unfavorable outcome from random chance
corre el riesgo ― it runs the risk

entonces.shortDef: then, next, thereupon, at that time, at that point
longDef: (Conjunction) then, next, thereupon, at that time, at that point
Desde entonces, siempre he tenido cuidado. ― Since then I've always been careful.
Entonces, el ladrón se fue. ― After that, the thief left.
Estaba lloviendo antes, entonces de seguro viniste con paraguas, ¿no?. ― It was raining before, so you certainly came in with an umbrella, didn't you?.
Que tengas una buena noche. ― Have a good night.
Que tengas un buen viaje. ― Have a good trip.
Synonyms: vale, de acuerdo, está bien
(used at the start of a phrase) well; a short pause in a sentence
Bueno, pues, mira. ― Well, then, look.
(Verb) to propose, to propound, to put forth, to put forward, to bring forward, to suggest
(Verb) to nominate (e.g., a candidate, a representative)

Cuando llegues a casa, mándame un mensaje. ― When you get home, send me a message.
2015 July 5, "Cocodrilos, ¡a desayunar!", in El País‎[1]:
Tratad de llegadme enteros que faltan más de tres semanas y os he traído aquí porque os necesito. ― (please add an English translation of this quotation)
(Verb) (intransitive) to get up to, to go up to (+ a or + hasta)
(Verb) to go out, to leave, to depart, to head out
(Verb) to go out, to come out (to leave one's abode to go to public places)

derribar.shortDef: to knockdown, to overthrow, toteardown, tothrowdown
longDef: (Verb) to bring down, to shoot down
(Verb) to knock down, to demolish, to break down, to tear down, to topple, to pull down, to kick down, to batter down
first-person singular present indicative of solar
first-person singular present indicative of soler: "I usually"
Suelo venir a las cinco. ― I usually come at five o’clock.

soler.shortDef: to be accustomed to, bein the habit of, have the custom of
longDef: (Verb) (auxiliary) to be accustomed to doing something, to do something on a regular basis, to do something usually or often
suele llegar tarde ― he usually arrives late
Por lo general no dice nada que merezca la pena oír, así que suelo simplemente ignorarlo. ― He generally doesn't say anything worth hearing, so I usually just ignore him.
(Verb) (transitive) to tie, tie up, tie down, to tether (secure (something) by rope or the like)
(Verb) (transitive) to constrain, limit (prevent or remove movement, leave (someone or something) without freedom of movement or ability to act)
(Noun) English or American foot (a unit of length equal to 30.48 cm)
first-person singular preterite indicative of piar

pi.shortDef: pi; the Greek letter Π, π

longDef: first-person singular present indicative of manar

bajo.shortDef: under (in both literal and figurative senses)
longDef: (Preposition) under (in both literal and figurative senses)
No hay nada nuevo bajo el sol. ― There's nothing new under the sun.
low, ground (situated close to the ground)
first-person singular present indicative of bajar

inflection of custodiar:
third-person singular present indicative
second-person singular imperative
los demás pasajeros ― the other passengers

playa.shortDef:
beach
1989, "Aquí no hay playa", performed by The Refrescos:
longDef: Afirmaréis seguros que es la capital de España / Pero al llegar agosto, ¡vaya, vaya! / Aquí no hay playa ― You will surely affirm that it is the capital of Spain / But when August arrives, wow, wow! / There is no beach here

Synonyms: mientras tanto, mientras
2016 December 16, "Page espera que el congreso del PSOE "no se cierre en falso" y sea "convergente"", in El País‎[1]:

Entretanto, los candidatables que más suenan miden sus fuerzas y otros de los que se habla en los mentideros socialistas como una opción intermedia, como Patxi López, guardan silencio: Sánchez desafió el sábado con un acto en Asturias al presidente de la gestora y del Principado, Javier Fernández, y esta tarde la presidenta de Andalucía, Susana Díaz, compartirá cartel con el expresidente José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero en un acto por el décimo aniversario de la Ley de Dependencia en Jaén. ― Meanwhile, the candidates that are making the most noise are measuring their strengths and others who are talked about among socialist gossip circles as an intermediate option, such as Patxi López, are silent: Sánchez challenged the president of the management and the Principality, Javier Fernández, on Saturday with an act in Asturias, and this afternoon the President of Andalusia, Susana Díaz, will share a poster with former President José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero in an act for the tenth anniversary of the Dependency Law in Jaén.
(Verb) (transitive) to hope for, hope to (often with a verb in the subjunctive)
esperar con interés ― to look forward to, to eagerly await
Espera que no sea necesario. ― He hopes it won't be necessary.
(Verb) (transitive) to expect, look for (often with a verb in the indicative)
Espera que no sea fácil. ― He expects it isn't easy.

inflection of impacientar:
first/third-person singular present subjunctive
third-person singular imperative
Preparados, listos, ya. ― Ready, set, go.
Ya lo hice. ― I already did it.
first (something) then (something else); first (something), now (something else)
¡Ya lluvia ya nieve! ― First rain, now snow!
ya sol ya lluvia ― whether sun or rain
Synonyms: vamos, vámonos, adelante, ándale, (Mexico) órale, (Chile) ya po
(colloquial) used to acknowledge or dismiss the previous statement
—Sabes que quedamos con Antonio esta tarde. —Ya. ― "You know we're hanging out with Antonio tonight." "I know."
—No podrás venir, que trabajas ese día. —Ya, pero cerramos temprano los viernes. ― "You can't come, you're working that day." "Right, but we close early on Fridays."
Vine, vi, vencí. ― I came, I saw, I conquered.
Sí, con mis propios ojos, lo vi robar el dinero. ― Yes, with my own eyes, I saw him steal the money.
(Verb) (transitive) to see, to look at, to view (perceive)
Hmm. Ya veo... ― Hmm. I see...
Tal experiencia única en la vida cambiará tu manera de ver el mundo. ― Such a once in a lifetime experience will change the way that you look at [or see or view] the world.

ola.shortDef: wave (on the surface of a liquid)
longDef: (Noun) wave (on the surface of a liquid)
(Noun) (figuratively) sudden appearance of a large amount of something
Oí ruidos extraños viniendo desde detrás de la puerta y tuve miedo. ― I heard strange noises coming from behind the door and got scared.
first-person singular present indicative of ventar
(Verb) (transitive) to not know; to be ignorant of
(Verb) (transitive) to ignore, to disregard (to deliberately not pay attention to)

subir.shortDef: to go up, rise, move up, climb, raise up
longDef: (Verb) to go up or come up
(Verb) (transitive) to look at (to try to see, to pay attention to with one’s eyes)
(Verb) (transitive) to watch (to look at, view, or observe for a period of time)
Estábamos mirando la televisión. ― We were watching TV.
Mi casa es pequeña, pero cómoda. ― My house is small, but comfortable.
(Conjunction) well well; so; well (used for emphasis)

borde.shortDef: edge, border, brink, verge, rim, margin
longDef: (Noun) edge, border, brink, verge, rim, margin
(Noun) brim, rim, lip (top edge of a vessel or container)

inflection of bordar:
first/third-person singular present subjunctive
third-person singular imperative
en la cima del mundo ― on top of the world
(Noun) peak, summit, mountaintop (top of a mountain or hill)

inflection of cimar:
third-person singular present indicative
second-person singular imperative
entry into a profession or organization

Construí un túnel entre tú y yo, y fue donde descubrí que se puede encontrar un camino para los dos. ― I built a tunnel between you and me, and [that] was where I discovered that a path for us both can be found.

nivel.shortDef: level, tier, height (distance relative to a given reference elevation)
longDef: (Noun) level, tier, height (distance relative to a given reference elevation)
(Verb) (intransitive) to disappear, to go missing, to vanish, to be gone
Mis llaves han desaparecido. ― My keys have disappeared.
(Verb) (intransitive) to drop off (e.g. the map, the face of the earth)
(Noun) (colloquial, familiar, endearing, in the plural) parents
second-person singular voseo imperative of papar

mío.shortDef: (predicative or after the noun) mine, my
longDef: (Determiner) (predicative or after the noun) mine, my
Ese libro grande es mío. ― That big book is mine.
No es lo mío. ― It's not my thing.
¿De quién son estos libros? — Son míos. Los tuyos están en la mesa. ― Whose books are these? — They're mine. Yours are on the table.
¿Dónde está tu madre? ― Where is your mother?
Olvidé mis llaves. ― I forgot my keys.
Olvidé mencionar el asunto. ― I forgot to mention the matter.

Ya olvidé lo que le dije. ― I already forgot what I told him.
1985, Gabriel García Márquez, El amor en los tiempos del cólera :
Hildebranda no había de olvidar jamás la primera visión del hombre que apareció en el estribo,  […]  ― Hildebranda was not to ever forget her first sight of the man that appeared on the stirrup, ...
(A mí) Se me olvidó. ― It eluded me.
Ya se me olvidó qué llevaba puesto. ― I already forgot what he was wearing.
Se me olvida siempre llamarte. ― I always forget to call you.
Un momento, señor. ― One moment, sir.
Fue un mal momento, así de simple. ― It was bad timing, plain and simple.
¡Buen  momento! Tengo el día libre. ― Good timing! I have the day off.
Lo acordaron por unanimidad. ― They agreed to it unanimously.
¿Qué camisa quiere? ― Which shirt do you want?
No sabía qué hacer ― I didn't know what to do
(before a noun) what a; such (used as an intensifier)
¡Qué casa más bonita! ― What a pretty house!
¡Qué mierda de tiempo! ― What shitty weather!
(before an adjective) how (used as a modifier to indicate surprise, delight, or other strong feelings)
If you are using a form of the verb ser, then unless you are asking the definition or meaning of something, you would use cuál even if in English, one would translate it as "what"
¿Cuál es su nombre? ― What is your name?
¿Cuál es el problema aquí? ― What is the problem here?

If in English, the interrogative pronoun "what" or "which" is operating as an adjective preceding the modified noun, then you would use qué and not cuál even if in English you might translate it as "which"
¿Qué medicamentos ha tomado en el pasado, señor? ― Which medications have you taken in the past, sir?
¿Qué pobre señorita ha capturado tu corazón esta vez? ― Which poor young lady has captured your heart this time?
¿Qué color de la pintura prefieres para las paredes del baño, rosa o marrón? ― Which color of paint do you prefer for the bathroom walls, pink or brown?
No sé que hago. ― I don't know what I'm doing.
Prefiero no hacerlo ― I prefer not to do it.
Empecemos a hacer el pastel. ― Let's start making the cake.
Le gustaba hacer poemas placenteros. ― She liked to make pleasant poems.
Nos quedan muchos haceres. ― We have a lot of tasks left.

Mi pobre vecino siempre está llorando. ― My poor neighbor is always crying.
2013, El sueño el Morfeo, Vuelve (a donde has venido):

El pasado ya es pasado, no tienes que pedir perdón. Solo déjanos tranquilos a mí y a mi pobre corazón. ― The past is the past, you don't have to ask forgiveness. Just leave us alone, me and my poor heart.
(Adjective) (after the noun) poor (lacking money, resources, etc.)
Se relajan las familias ricas en casas lujosas y las familias pobres tiran en chozas desmoronadas. ― The rich families relax in luxurious houses and the poor families get by in dilapidated huts.

inflection of mechar:
third-person singular present indicative
second-person singular imperative

demasiado.shortDef: too much, excessively, far too much, overmuch (modifying a verb)
longDef: (Adverb) too much, excessively, far too much, overmuch (modifying a verb)
Él se queja demasiado. ― He complains too much.
(Adverb) too, far too,  way too, much too, overly, all too excessively (modifying an adjective or other adverb)
Hablas demasiado rápido. ― You're speaking too fast.
demasiado poco, demasiado tarde ― too little, too late
Ellos beben demasiado licor. ― They drink too much liquor.
Amiga, ha pasado demasiado tiempo. ― Friend, it's been too long.

coger.shortDef: to seize, to take, tograsp, tograb, tocatch
longDef: (Verb) (Colombia, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Peru, Philippines, Puerto Rico, Spain) to take, catch, hold, to get, to seize

cuanto.shortDef: as much; however much; in whatever quantity
longDef: (Adverb) as much; however much; in whatever quantity
as much [of]; as many; however much; however many
Bebe cuanta agua quieres. ― Drink as much water as you want.
(after "unos") few; quite a few; a handful
Coge unos cuantos. ― Take a handful (a few).
whatever quantity, as much, however much
Dame cuanto tengas. ― Give me however many you have.
Synonyms: cerilla, (Mexico) cerillo, (regional, Spain) misto, (regional, Spain) mixto

probar.shortDef: to test, to prove, totry, totryon
longDef: No puedes probarlo. ― You can’t prove it.
(Verb) (transitive) to reach; to attain or achieve; to catch up with
(Verb) (transitive, intransitive, reflexive) to feel like, to fancy; would like, to be down for (US slang)
No me apetece salir esta noche. ― I don't feel like going out tonight.
¿Te apetece ayudarme con esto? ― Do you feel like helping me with this?
Me apetece una pizza con champiñones. ― I'm in the mood for a pizza with mushrooms.
Aunque es importante, nadie lo considera así. ― Although it is important, nobody considers it so.
Voy a juntarme con los amigos, aunque tengo mucho que hacer por la mañana ― I'm going to meet up with friends, even though I have a lot to do in the morning.
(Conjunction) even if, irrespective of (followed by subjunctive verb form)
Mañana me voy aunque llueva. ― I'm leaving tomorrow even if it rains.

Aunque se dé cuenta de que todavía no he hecho lo que pidió, espero que no se enoje. No es que no sepa que ya tengo muchas otras cosas que hacer. ― Even if he realizes I still haven't done what he asked, I hope he doesn't get upset. It's not like he doesn't know that I already have a lot of other things to do.
(Verb) (transitive, reflexive or non-reflexive) to put, to put up, to place, to lay
Pon eso en su lugar. ― Put that in its place.
Pongamos el plan a la espera por ahora. ― Let's put the plan on hold for now.
Puse un anuncio en Craigslist. ― I put up an ad on Craigslist.
(Verb) (transitive) to set, to set up (e.g. set an alarm, set up chairs)
Voy a poner la mesa ― I'm going to set the table.

inflection of mesar:
third-person singular present indicative
second-person singular imperative
¿Estás todavía escribiendo? ― Are you still writing?
Helado es todavía mejor. ― Frozen is even better.

faltar.shortDef: to lack, be lacking, be missing
longDef: (Verb) (intransitive, or transitive with a or de) to be lacking, lack, not have
Te falta imaginación. ― You lack imagination.
¿Cuánto tiempo falta? ― How much time left?
Falta un mes para mi cumpleaños. ― My birthday is a month away.
Comí poco. ― I ate little / I didn’t eat much.
Bebí poca agua. ― I drank little water.
Nos casamos hace poco tiempo. ― We got married recently.
(literally, "We got married a little time ago.")
Muy pocas personas hacen eso. ― Very few people do that.
Hablo un poco (de) inglés. ― I speak a little English.
a short time, a little while
hace poco ― a little while ago
dentro de poco ― in a little bit
(Verb) (intransitive) to go (away from speaker and listener)
Nos gusta ir al cine. ― We like to go to the movies.
(Verb) (intransitive) to come (towards or with the listener)
Quiero ir contigo. ― I want to come with you.
Iré a tu casa. ― I'll come to your house.
to leave a mark on (the skin)
Ven cuando estés listo. ― Come when you're ready.
first-person singular present indicative of librar
(Verb) (transitive) to save, to rescue, to deliver, to preserve
(Verb) (intransitive) to use to (be in the habit of)
Quiero leer el periódico. ― I want to read the newspaper.

Léase también la Orden General núm. 8. ― Also read General Order No. 8.
1605, Miguel de Cervantes, El ingenioso hidalgo Don Quijote de la Mancha, Primera parte:

[…]  y llegó a tanto su curiosidad y desatino en esto, que vendió muchas hanegas de tierra de sembradura para comprar libros de caballerías en que leer, y, así, llevó a su casa todos cuantos pudo haber dellos. ―  […]  to such a pitch did his eagerness and infatuation go that he sold many an acre of tillage land to buy books of chivalry to read, and brought home as many of them as he could get.
neuter definite article used to make abstract nouns from adjectives; the

traer.shortDef: to bring, to get, fetch, to carry
longDef: ¿Qué te trae por aquí? ― What brings you here?
Voy a traerle una cerveza ― I'm going to bring you a beer.
first-person singular present indicative of rayar
first-person singular present indicative of raer
(Verb) to avoid, to bypass, to evade, to circumvent, to dodge, to shun, to eschew (to steer clear of)
Después de haberlo evitado muchas horas, acabó por decirnos la verdad. ― After having avoided it for several hours, he ended up telling us the truth.
(Verb) to avoid, to prevent, to keep from, to stop from, to avert, to obviate, to deter

huir.shortDef: to escape, to flee, torunaway, toslipaway

longDef: first-person singular present indicative of sitiar
las ocho de la mañana ― eight in the morning
Él se levanta por las mañanas. ― He gets up in the mornings.
en un día del mañana ― someday in the near future
pasado mañana ― the day after tomorrow
mañana por la mañana ― tomorrow morning
Lo siguiente que puedo recordar es que salí corriendo. ― The next thing I can remember was running out.
El lugar donde estamos es secreto. ― The place where we are is secret.
(in indirect questions) where, in what place
Deja los libros donde quieras. ― Leave the books where you want.
Estamos donde la plaza mayor. ― We're around by the main square.
Cenamos donde Daniel. ― We're having dinner (round) at Daniel's place.
(Verb) (transitive) to throw, to hurl, to toss, to fling (cause an object to move rapidly through the air)
(Verb) (transitive) to emit (to send out or give off)
Synonyms: chamba, empleo, faena, quehacer, tarea, curro, laburo
Es un trabajo duro, pero alguien tiene que hacerlo. ― It’s a tough job, but someone’s got to do it.
first-person singular present indicative of trabajar
Hemos prometido que lo pasado, pasado está. ― We promised to let bygones be bygones.
